H0.text: Electrons are most likely located with the quarks in an atom.

H1.text: With the neutrons, electrons are most likely located in an atom.

H2.text: Outside the nucleus is where electrons are most likely located in an atom.

H3.text: Near the protons is where electrons most likely are located in an atom.

A4.text: In atoms, an electron's matter wave occupies atomic orbitals around a positively charged atomic nucleus.

A5.text: Electrons are bound to the nucleus to different degrees.

A6.text: The electron will eventually lose energy (by releasing a photon) and drop into the lower orbital.

A7.text: Electrons are never in a single point location, though the probability of interacting with the electron at a single point can be found from the electron's wave function.
